explanation:
Correct calculation: \(9 \times \sqrt{3} = 9\sqrt{3}\) (no simplification possible since 3 has no square factors).  
Student's incorrect calculation: \(9 \times \sqrt{3} = \sqrt{9 \times 3} = \sqrt{27}\).  

The error occurs when converting \(9\sqrt{3}\) to a single radical. The student incorrectly placed the coefficient 9 directly under the radical without squaring it first. To express \(a\sqrt{b}\) as \(\sqrt{a^2 \times b}\), the coefficient must be squared. Here, \(9\sqrt{3}\) would correctly become \(\sqrt{81 \times 3} = \sqrt{243}\), not \(\sqrt{27}\).  

This matches the misconception of treating the coefficient as a multiplier for the existing radicand instead of squaring it before combining. The student mistakenly applied \(a\sqrt{b} = \sqrt{a \times b}\) rather than \(\sqrt{a^2 \times b}\).  

This differs from "squares the number under the radical" (which would imply \(9\sqrt{3} = \sqrt{9 \times 3^2}\)) or "multiplies coefficients but fails to multiply under the radical" (which would leave \(9\sqrt{3}\) unchanged). The error is specific to mishandling the coefficient-to-radical conversion.
